No response.

Hey Arun, glad to have you contributing.  It looks like you need to get added to the Intel CLA.  I believe Terry Duncan maintains it these days (or should at least be able to point you to the right person).

That will get you a CI run, which should find a lot of the quick issues that CI can find.

Given that this is implementing a generic thing (Licenses) that is going to need to work across CPU and component vendors, this is probably the kind of thing that needs a design doc so we can get the implementation in place and the interfaces nailed down.  Ideally we would've done that before we wrote so much implementation, but no big deal, we'll work it out in the end.


Based on the looks of it, this code was written a while ago, as I see a lot of the current best practices seem to be missed or were copied from old code.  In many cases I've pointed out only one instance, but there are multiple that need fixed, so please work through your code and fix all of them.


As an overall theme, this patchset needs to be using the mapper to find these license objects.  Calling a single daemon locks bmcweb into ONLY supporting CPU licenses, or maintaining a list of every possible daemon that can implement a license, so for that reason, we rely on the mapper to maintain a list of deamons for us, so please plan on porting your code to use that.


If you have any questions and want faster response times, Gunnar, Krzysztof, and myself are all active on discord (as are a bunch of other bmcweb users), and can help you out.

Again, glad to have you contributing!
removed

Please don't hardcode service names for things that are distributed across the project.  use the mapper to look them up, or, if the intent is for this service to handle all licenses for all projects, please make that clear when you push the design docs for this.
removed hardcoded service name and used the GetObject mapper method to get the service name.

I really suspect this helper method is already covered by some combination of the boost::urls::url object, or pulling the "name" from the router string.  We do this exact same conversion other places without needing this helper function, so please try to use those as an example.  If this is truly required, Please explain in your commit message why, and how it differs from the existing.
removed this helper function and used boost::url library functions in the latest patch set
nit, else is redundant here.
removed
if you expect 1 device, and there's 0 or > 1, you need to handle that error appropriately.
Handled the error appropriately
else is redundant here.
removed
Please don't capture references like this in async handlers. They cause lifetime issues, as pointers are invalidated anytime the calling object is modified.  We have hit this bug a lot.
removed reference

Please:
1. avoid nlohmann brace construction
2. use the urlFromPieces to ensure that your urls are escaped properly.
3. deduplicate your branches.  They are largely identical except for "ProvisionLicense" or "DyanmicLicense".  I suspect that could just be the value of "method" and remove a lot of the complication here.
done as per the suggestion
Please don't do these types of casts to map ints to enum values.  They are implementation defined, and lack error handling for responses that don't map.
type casted the response code to enum for comparison like elsewhere

Because of the aggregation work, we are trying to remove all brace initialization of jsonValue from this.  Please look around at other examples of the style that's currently on master using operator[], and replicate it here.
removed brace initialization
This seems like an odd thing to hardcode, and I'm not sure it's right, please take a look and advise.
removed this property since its not a mandatory property.
another example of brace initialization of nlohaman objects.
removed brace initialization
Please follow the naming convention we have for callbacks like this elsewhere.
updated the function name
Considering this is trying to make use of oem stuff, we'll need to figure out how to map that to dbus in an agnostic way.
Can you please point out an example where we handle this kind of oem properties? Do we need to keep a separate patch for oem stuff to differentiate it from standard properties?

Please parse this using the mulit-level support in readJsonPatch

Ie, this should be

"Links/AuthorizationScope" I think.
used mulit-level support in readJsonPatch (Links/AuthorizedDevices)

This isn't really a correct type check.  for example linksObject could be uint64_t, which would also be incorrect.

please just use the built-in handling in readJson, which handles these types of safety issues (and lots more) for you directly.
removed the type check and handled accordingly
This is kind of an odd check, considering that we read this in, then do nothing with the parameter?

As per the schema Authorization scope support all those 4 values. So if AuthScope has a value other than those four we can return it with error. Also we are validating authscope specifically for CPULicense. So again this is going to be validated based on the License Type. This is just the general validation.
Ack

We'll have to discuss that in the PDI review.  I suspect this isn't something we're going to want to hardcode in the front end, given that anything (including things like nvdimms that intel cares about) can have a license string, and we don't want to maintain a "everything that could be licensed" list here.
Please don't parse urls with regex.  We have dedicated structures (boost::urls::url) for parsing urls in a way that is consistent with escaping rules.
removed URL parsing with regex
Again, please prefer to invert this check and return early (although with url parsing, it might not be neccesary anymore.
removed
This is just renaming a variable?  Doesn't seem neccesary?
removed
You're mixing schemas here.  earlier in this file you treated Links as an object, here you're treting it as an array.  I don't remember which is correct in the standard, but one of them is wrong.
Removed this error message

Lots of stuff to fix here, and on every other BMCWEB_ROUTE declaration:

1. Please use the privilege registry declarations for LicenseCollection.  If they don't yet exist in the base privilege registry, please work with DMTF to get them added.  Both Gunnar and I are on the DMTF and attend the meeting regularly, so if you show up or file PR with them, ping CC both of us and we're happy to help get your changes through.

2. You seem to have missed the "setupRedfishRoute()" call that we now require for redfish tree changes to make sure query params work properly.  Please add that to all of your requests (take a look at any other example in the tree).


3. You've written most of these as lambdas, which we've been transitioning our existing lambdas to direct function calls with std::bind_front.  Please take a look elsewhere for examples of this.


Please make all 3 changes to every BMCWEB_ROUTE invocation in this patchset.
Fixed as per the all the above comments
This check is not required, and is actually guaranteed by the router to never happen.  Even if it does, it generally causes no functional issues if it's empty.
removed
Please invert this check and return early on errors.
As of now we have implemented it consdering mainly the CPU Licenses. All other licenses when implemented should comes under the else part. This function call is used to identify the license type
So all the licenses when implemented should come under else.

Please don't capture req by reference, as it causes lifetime issues on async calls if the connection drops while a request handling is in process.  Parse out the fields you need, and pass those by value to your callback.
Removed &req
common error #12.  Please read and understand COMMON_ERRORS.md
Added the validation for service empty together with the current validation like else where.
what is sdsi, and why do we put is as part of the lookup path?
removed and used the global variable already defined
nit, const char* please to avoid the std::string construction.
used const char* instead of std::string
please link the phosphor-dbus-interfaces review for this.  I suspect this naming is overly specific, and is going to be requested to be more abstracted, but lets talk about that in the right review.

Lots more details needed here.  Is there a design doc for this work (link it)?  What dbus interfaces does it use?  (Link the phosphor-dbus-interfaces review)

What is this used for?  Why would someone implement this?

> @Ed this is in relation to the conversation you and I had on Discord a while back. To recap, Intel and AMI are still working on the service that will use the License schema and it will be a while before we are ready with it. 
>  
> We felt we should share this ahead of time to get feedback from the community.

I can only give as much feedback as can be seen, and 

> Also incase there are others interested in License schema this will give them a head start. 

Please start by pushing a phosphor-dbus-interfaces review, so we can discuss your interface in the right forum.  This patchset isn't the right place to discuss it.

> 
> Last time we spoke, you had mentioned we can get the gerrit review to a merge-able point until Intel/AMI is ready other pieces. Is that still ok?

Yep, just that phosphor-dbus-interfaces needs to come first (and ideally should've been pushed and discussed before this patch, but that's ok).
what is SDSi?
Removed the term SDSi from commit messgae
There's still a file called SDSi helper.
Please get added to your companies CLA.  This will allow CI to trigger, and expose some work to do (this patch doesn't build in CI as-is by looking at it).
NIt there is a typo in the subject, remove the y from yAdding.
